casebody.data:
Goodwin v. Taylor executor of Williamson. Devise to E.. C., the testator’s daughter, of the interest of 4000Z. government securities, during her life, and at her death, the interest of the said 4000Í. to go to his four granddaughter’s equally, and at their decease, the principal and interest to be disposed of by them to their heirs. E. C. released to the husband of one of the grand-daughters all her right to the interest of 1000Í. of the said securities. The grand-daughter dying in the life-time of E, C., her husband, as her ¡administrator, filed a bill to recover the said 1000Í., which was decreed accordingly. *96Thomas Williamson, by his will dated in 1787, de vised as follows, viz. “ I give to my daughter Elizabeth Clements, the interest of 4000/. in government func^s during her life, and at her death, I give the interest of the above money, one fourth to each of my grand-children S. Cocke, Elizabeth Clements, Frances Clements, and John Clements, and at their decease, the principal and interest to be disposed of by them to their heirs, in such proportions, as they by their wills respectively may direct, and in case of the death of my grand-daughter Sarah Cocke without issue, I give her part to my grand-daughter Elizabeth ClementsP Elizabeth Clements the daughter of the testator, by deed duly executed, released to the plaintiff Goodwin and to his wife Elizabeth, hex daughter, and the granddaughter of the testator, all her right and title in and to the interest of 1000/. of the said certificates. The grand-daughter died in the life-time of her mother, intestate, and the plaintiff, as her administrator filed his bill in the County Court of Southampton, to recover possession of 1000/. of the said certificates.

(1) Higginbotham v. Runker, 2 Call. 313, Newby’s adm. v. Blakey, 3 Hen. H Munf. 57. 60.

The Court decreed the defendant to pay and deliver to the plaintiff 1000/. of the certificates in the public funds, bequeathed by Thomas Williamson to Elizabeth the late wife of the plaintiff.

From this decree an appeal was prayed to the High Court of Chancery, where it was reversed anti the bill dismissed ; from which an appeal was taken to this Court, where the decree of the High Court of Chancery was reversed, and that of the County Court affirmed(1)
